intro: Mackinlaya confusa, commonly known as the New Zealand broom, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant typically grows in coastal and forested areas, thriving in well-drained soils. It produces yellow flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
